intro: Uncinia macloviana var. montana, commonly known as the mountain hookweed, is a perennial herb native to high-altitude regions of South America. It is characterized by its slender, upright stems and small, lance-shaped leaves that are often covered in fine hairs. The plant produces tiny, greenish-white flowers arranged in dense, spike-like clusters, which bloom in late summer. Its fibrous roots are adapted to nutrient-poor soils, allowing it to thrive in rocky, mountainous environments. The species is notable for its resilience to cold temperatures and high UV exposure.
